body: I craned my neck around from the window to the library entrance. An old man in a Hawaiian shirt slipped in from the glass-door entrance, but besides that it was empty. I glanced at the clock in the corner of my computer. 8:30pm. Grace wasn’t here yet.

We’d been friends since <CHOICE(A)> but I wanted to get the meeting <CHOICE(B)> with. It had been so long since we hung out, and she’d want to know <CHOICE(C)> to me since we’d last spoken. We’d signed up for the same Intro to Theater class, me sitting in the back and her in the front. It made sense: I wanted an easy class, and she wanted to begin her journey of a Very Serious Theater Major. This would be the first time we’d really talked with each other; we’d been brought together, of all things, by a peer-review our  monologues.

Oh, God, the monologue. I sharpened my vision back down at my computer and changed tabs to the steaming pile of garbage I’d produced; I couldn’t write to save my life. I used words like fancy colleges used rejection letters: they were disappointing and sometimes made people cry. I couldn’t even bear to read a <CHOICE(D)> of what I’d written, and now Grace had to give me feedback.
